The eighth lord of theTatsuno domain of the Province of Harima

sen.j: 脇坂氏は元外様大名であり、入譜代、つまり外様から願って譜代格に直してもらった家柄ではあったが、外様の家系は幕府の役職には就けないのが慣例であった。
sen.e: Although the Wakisaka clan was family lineage of the former Tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord), who wished to become 入譜代, the rank of fudai (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) from Tozama, there was a custom that anyone from Tozama family lineage could not get official position of Edo bakufu. (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)
sen.cmt: 入譜代→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: Although the Wakisaka clan was a family lineage of the former Tozama daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord), who wished to become 入譜代, the rank of fudai (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) from Tozama, there was a custom that anyone from Tozama family lineage could not be appointed to an official position in the Edo bakufu. (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

The Wakisaka clan was formerly related to a nonhereditary feudal lord, who applied for the rank of hereditary feudal lord, i.e., applied to the goverment for raising of the clan from a nonhereidtary feudal lord to a hereditary feudal lord, but there was a custom that prevented the descendants of nonhereditary feudal lord family from being appointed to an official position in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし安董は弁舌がさわやかで、押し出しも良く男ぶりも良かったといわれ、これが征夷大将軍徳川家斉の目にとまり、異例のことながら寛政3年（1791年）、寺社奉行に登用された。
sen.e: With an exception, since Yasutada was good speaker and very assertive and brave, Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo, Ienari TOKUGAWA took attention of him and he was appointed to jisha-bugyo in 1791.

During this period, Yasutada passed judgements on two incidents, one was the Enmei-in Temple (present-day, in Arakawa Ward) in Yanaka (present-day Taito Ward) Incident and the other one was the Incident that Disturbed the Three Deeds.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.e: Yanaka Enmei-in Temple Incident was the incident which involved the servant of O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside) and there was a female criminal who caused the scandal.

The Yanaka Enmei-in Temple Incident was a scandal of female criminal that involved a servant of O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside).

sen.j: 当時の延命院住持は日潤といい、歌舞伎役者尾上菊五郎の隠し子だと言われる（異説もある）。
sen.e: The chief priest of Chimein Temple at that time was called Nichijun and there was a theory that he was said to be an illegitimate child of Kabuki actor, Kikugoro ONOUE. (there is another theory exist as well.)
The chief priest of Chimein Temple at that time was called Nichijun and it was theorized that he was an illegitimate child of the Kabuki actor, Kikugoro ONOUE. (a different theory exists as well.)

The chief priest of the Enmei-in Temple at that time was called Nichijun, and it was theorized that he was an illegitimate child of the Kabuki actor, Kikugoro ONOUE (a different theory exists as well).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Enmei-in Templeに訂正しました。ピリオド訂正しました。

sen.j: この日潤が多数の大奥女中と密通しているという噂が飛び、享和3年（1803年）、安董は女密偵も使って慎重に内偵を進めた。
sen.e: There was a rumor that this Nichijun had affairs with maids of O-oku, Yasutada hired secret female spy to look into the incident cautiously, then he went to Enmei-in Temple to arrest Nichijun and other apostates, after Nichijun was sentenced to death penalty, Yasutada suddenly became famous.

There was a rumor that Nichijun had affairs with maids of O-oku, so Yasutada hired a secret female spy to look into the incident cautiously. He then went to Enmei-in Temple to arrest Nichijun and other apostates. After Nichijun was sentenced to death, Yasutada gained sudden fame.
There was a rumor that Nichijun had affairs with the maids of O-oku; so in 1803, Yasutada hired a female spy to look into the incident carefully.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 5月26日 (旧暦)、みずから延命院に踏み込んで日潤ら破戒坊主を検挙した。
sen.e: Then he raided the Enmei-in Temple to arrest Nichijun and other apostates on July 14.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。(旧暦）注釈削除しました。

sen.j: 日潤は7月29日 (旧暦)に死刑に処され、一気に令名を馳せた。
sen.e: Yasutada gained sudden fame after Nichijun was sentenced to death on September 14.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。(旧暦）注釈削除しました。

sen.j: 「三業惑乱」は、西本願寺の教義をめぐる争論である。
sen.e: The Sango Wakuran Controversy was the incident to fight over creed of Nishihongai-ji Temple.
The Sango Wakuran Controversy was an incident where a dispute occurred over the creed of the Nishihongai-ji Temple.
The Sango Wakuran Controversy was an incident where disputes occurred over the creed of the Nishihongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 幕府当局は各教団の宗旨や教義をめぐる争論には介入を控えるのが通例であったが、本件では一部信者が本山に集団で詰め掛けようとするなど穏当ならざる騒ぎになったため、事案が寺社奉行にもちこまれたわけである。
sen.e: It was tradition that the bakufu did not get involved into conflict in relation to creed and religious Doctrine of each religious group, however it caused a problem when a group of believers of a certain religion came to Honzan, so the matter was brought to jisha-bugyo to solve.

Traditionally the bakufu did not get involved in conflicts relating to creed and religious doctrine, when a group of believers of a certain religion came to Honzan, they caused such a disturbance that the matter was brought before the jisha-bugyo.

Traditionally the bakufu did not get involved in conflicts relating to creed and religious doctrine, but in this case, a disturbance was developped bigger as a group of believers of the sect were to come to the head temple, the matter was brought before the Magistrate of Temples and Shrines.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Templesと訂正しました。

sen.j: 安董は真宗大谷派の香月院深励に影響され仏教教義に通暁していたこともあり、かなり突っ込んだ調べを行っている。
sen.e: Since Yasutada was acquainted with Buddhism creed after getting influenced by Kagetsu-in Jinrei of Shinshu sect Otani school, he conducted detailed investigation.
Since Yasutada was acquainted with Buddhism creed after being influenced by Kagetsu-in Jinrei of the Shinshu sect Otani school, he conducted a detailed investigation.
Since Yasutada was acquainted with Buddhism doctorin after being influenced by Kagetsu-in Jinrei of the Shinshu sect Otani school, he conducted a detailed investigation.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 双方より聴聞を行い、文化 (元号)3年（1806年）7月11日 (旧暦)、判決を下し、西本願寺に対し宗門不取締の咎ありとした。
sen.e: He had hearing from both parties, the decision was made on July 11, 1806, which said Nishihongan-ji Temple should be punished for not controlling the doctrine, however considering that this was the conflict in relation to religious creed, Nichihongan-ji Temple had minor punishment of closing the temple for one hundred days.

He conducted hearings with both parties, and a decision was made on July 11, 1806, which said Nishihongan-ji Temple should be punished for not controlling the doctrine, however considering that this was a conflict in relation to religious creed, Nichihongan-ji Temple only faced minor punishment which involved closing the temple for one hundred days.
He conducted hearings with both parties, and a decision was made on August 24, 1806, which said the Nishihongan-ji Temple should be punished for not controlling the doctrine.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: しかし、宗教の教義をめぐる争論であることも考慮し、100日間閉門という微罪処分で済ませた。
sen.e: However considering that this was a conflict in relation to religious creed, the Nishihongan-ji Temple only faced minor punishment which involved closing the temple for one hundred days.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。

sen.j: この脇坂の判決は名裁きであると、老中首座松平信明 (三河吉田藩主)からも賞されている。
sen.e: This decision of Wakisaka was praised as making excellent decision by shuso (the leader of monks practicing asceticism) of roju, Nobuaki MATSUDAIRA. (the lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida domain)
Wakisaka's decision was praised by shuso (the leader of monks practicing asceticism) of roju, Nobuaki MATSUDAIRA. (the lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida domain) as being excellent.

sen.j: このように安董は辣腕ぶりをみせたのだが、自身の妾のことで讒にあって失脚、寺社奉行を辞任する。
sen.e: Although Yasutada proved himself as an able person, he lost his position of jisha-bugyo and resigned since he was abused by someone in relation to his mistress.
Although Yasutada proved himself to be an able person, he lost his position as jisha-bugyo and resigned because due to slander which was created based on his relation to his mistress.

Although Yasutada proved himself to be an able person, he lost his position as the Magistrate of Temples and Shrines and resigned due to slander which was created based on his relation to his mistress.

sen.j: その後安董は龍野藩政に専念していたが、16年後、将軍家斉のお声掛りで再び寺社奉行に起用される。
sen.e: After that Yasutada was focusing on ruling the Tatsuno domain, after sixteen years, he was again appointed to Jishabugyo by Shogun, Ienari.
After that Yasutada focused on ruling the Tatsuno domain, after sixteen years, he was again appointed to Jishabugyo by Shogun, Ienari.
After that, Yasutada focused on ruling the Tatsuno Domain, and sixteen years later, he was reappointed the Magistrate of Temples and Shrines by the Shogun, Ienari.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Templesに訂正しました。the補足しました。

sen.j: この再起用には幕府内外の事情通も首を捻った。
sen.e: Some people, outside and inside of the bakufu, did not agreed for Yasutada to be appointed as Jishabugyo, there was one theory that Yasutada was appointed because Ienari got fed up with continuous scandal caused by maids of O-oku since Enmei-in Temple incident, Yasudata was expected to investigate and solve the problem.

Some people, outside and inside of the bakufu, did not agreed that Yasutada be appointed as Jishabugyo. Some people outside and inside of the bakufu, did not agree that Yasutada should be appointed as the Magistrate of Temples and Shrines.

sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 事実、あいも変わらずスキャンダルまみれの寺社関係者は安董再登場に震え上った。
sen.e: In fact, some people from temples and shrines who lived with enough scandals same as before, were afraid of Yasutada's come back and there was a lampoon went around in Edo saying, 'Monks were shocked to see marten again' ('marten' means Wakisaka, please refer to the chapter of Yasuharu WAKISAKA in relation to the reason for it.)

In fact, some people from temples and shrines who had lived with these scandals, were afraid of Yasutada's return. There was a lampoon that went around in Edo saying, 'Monks were shocked to see marten again' ('marten' means Wakisaka, please refer to the chapter of Yasuharu WAKISAKA for the reason.)
In fact, some people in temples and shrines involved with these scandals, were afraid of Yasutada's return.

sen.j: 江戸には、「また出たと 坊主びっくり 貂の皮」（「貂の皮」は脇坂を指す、謂については脇坂安治の項参照のこと）という落首が出回った。
sen.e: There was a lampoon which went around Edo saying, 'Monks were shocked to see marten again' ('marten' means Wakisaka, please refer to the chapter of "Yasuharu WAKISAKA" for the reason.)

sen.j: しかし安董はなぜか寺社の風儀紊乱には手をつけず、沈黙を守っていた。
sen.e: However Yasutada did not deal with the corruption of public morals of the temples and shrines for some reason, and kept silence.
However, for some unknown reason Yasutada kept silence, and did not deal with the corruption of public morals in the temples and shrines.
However, for some unknown reason Yasutada kept quiet, and did not deal with the corruption of public morals in the temples and shrines.

sen.j: ところで、文政年間より但馬国出石藩の仙石氏では当主の家督相続問題や藩政の運営をめぐって仙石左京と仙石造酒の両家老が派閥をなして対立がくすぶっていた。
sen.e: By the way, from Bunsei era there was conflict of the Sengoku clan in the domain of Izushi in the Province of Tajima, especially between two Karo (chief retainer), Sakyo SENGOKU and Miki SENGOKU in relation to succession to (the head position in) a family issue or ruling the domain.

Also, from the Bunsei era there was a conflict with the Sengoku clan in the domain of Izushi in the Province of Tajima, especially between two Karo (chief retainer), Sakyo SENGOKU and Miki SENGOKU in relation to the issue concerning family succession (the head position in) and rule of the domain.

On the other hand, from the Bunsei era, there was a conflict within the Sengoku clan in the Izushi Domain of the Tajima Province, especially between the factions of the two chief retainers Sakyo SENGOKU and Miki SENGOKU over the issue concerning the family succession and the rule of the domain.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。Domain大文字にしました。

sen.j: 天保6年（1835年）になると造酒派の藩士神谷転（かみや・うたた）は脱藩して虚無僧に身を替えて江戸に潜伏し、左京の非道を幕府に訴願する機会をうかがっていたが、左京はいち早く老中首座松平康任に手を回し、康任は南町奉行筒井政憲に神谷を捕縛させた。
sen.e: In 1835, feudal retainers of Miki group, Utata KAMIYA left the domain and pretended to be komuso (begging Zen priest of the Fuke sect (wearing a sedge hood and playing a shakuhachi bamboo flute) staying in Edo, he was waiting for the occasion to an appeal bakufu of unjust action of Sakyo, however Sakyo made a quick move to have roju, Yasuto MATSUDAIRA to be on his side, and Yasuto let Minamimachi Bugyo(Magistrate), Masanori TSUTSUI arrest KAMIYA.

In 1835, feudal retainers of Miki group, Utata KAMIYA left the domain and pretended to be komuso (begging Zen priest of the Fuke sect wearing a sedge hood and playing a shakuhachi bamboo flute) staying in Edo, he was waiting for an occasion to appeal to the bakufu for the unjust action by Sakyo, however Sakyo made a quick move to bring roju, Yasuto MATSUDAIRA on his side, and Yasuto let Minamimachi Bugyo(Magistrate), Masanori TSUTSUI arrested KAMIYA.

In 1835, Utata KAMIYA, a feudal retainer of the Miki group, left the domain and pretended to be a begging Zen priest staying in Edo, waiting for an occasion to appeal the injustice by Sakyo to the bakufu; however, Sakyo made a quick move to bring the head of the shogun's council of elders, Yasuto MATSUDAIRA, to his side and had Yasuto order the South town Magistrate of Edo, Masanori TSUTSUI, to arrest Kamiya.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。不要なスペースを削除しました。Kamiyaに訂正しました。

sen.j: しかし虚無僧の管轄は寺社方であり、外見からは神谷が虚無僧に身を替えていたのは信仰を理由としたものか、それとも別の思惑からなのかは判然としない。
sen.e: However, it was Temple's responsibility to regulate komuso, and it was not clear the reason why KAMIYA changed his outlook to pretend to be komuso, whether he had religious intention or he had another thought.

However, it was the Temple's responsibility to regulate komuso, and the reason was not clear as to why KAMIYA changed his outlook to pretend to be komuso, whether he had religious intentions or had another thought.

However, it was the Temple's responsibility to regulate begging Zen priests, and the reason was not clear as to why Kamiya changed his outlook to pretend to be the begging Zen priest, whether he had religious intentions or had another thought.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。不要なピリオドを削除しました。Kamiyaに訂正しました。

sen.j: そこで事件は寺社奉行、町奉行、公事方勘定奉行で構成される評定所に舞台を移し、将軍家斉より、この一件は安董が専管すべしという指図を受け、調査を開始した。
sen.e: Then this incident was examined in Hyojosho (conference chamber), which was structured by jisha-bugyo, a town magistrate, Kujikatakanjo Bugyo (Magistrate), Shogun Ienari ordered Yasutada to investigate this case specially, and Yasutada started the investigation.

sen.j: 本件は寺社奉行吟味物調役の川路弥吉（のちの川路聖謨）の綿密な調査協力もあり、左京は獄門、出石藩は3万石の減封、また老中松平康任は失脚という形で幕を閉じる（仙石騒動）。

(the Sengoku Disturbance)

This incident was concluded with the help of Jisha bugyo ginmimonoshirabeyaku,Yakichi KAWAJI's (later called Toshiakira KAWAJI) careful investigation, Sakyo was imprisoned, Izushi clan was ordered to decrease their territory of thirty thousand koku, roju, and Yasuto MATSUDAIRA lost his position (the Sengoku Disturbance).

After this incident, Yasutada was promoted to the rank of Nishinomaru Roju and was appointed as the aides of Shogun's successor, Iesada TOKUGAWA, furthermore, he was promoted to Honmaru Roju.

Despite his successful promotion, he died while he was roju.
